title-group.article-title: Measurement of Quality of Life in Menopausal Women
title-group.subtitle: A Systematic Review

abstract.p: Use of a wide variety of quality of life (QoL) instruments, each measuring a different aspect of menopause with a different type of underlying scale, has been a major problem in menopause research. The aim of this review was to identify instruments developed for menopausal women and evaluate the psychometric properties and appropriateness of instruments for the study of QoL in menopausal women. Seven measures from 16 papers were chosen for the review. The psychometric evaluations were conducted based on quality judgment criteria. Of the seven measures reviewed in this study, the psychometric quality scores of Women’s Health Questionnaire (WHQ) was the highest. However, the result indicates that most instruments of menopause-specific QoL need further testing and evaluation of the various aspects of their psychometric properties. In addition, future research assessing psychometric properties with cross-cultural samples may be beneficial in adapting measures to specific context and study populations.

body.p: Menopause is a natural transition encompassing not only the biological changes but also the social and cultural changes associated with the aging process (Hunt, 2000; Schneider, 2002; Zöllner, Acquadro, & Schaefer, 2005). It usually occurs sometime between 40 and 60 years and marks the end of the reproductive phase of a women’s life (Mishra & Kuh, 2010). The whole process of transition from premenopause to postmenopause may take more than 10 years (Alder, 2002). During these years, many women experience physical changes including hot flushes, sleep disorders, fatigue, and sexual dysfunction as well as psychological changes, such as depression, anxiety, and irritability (Freedman, 2002; Mishra & Kuh, 2010). All of these symptoms and experiences may affect the daily life of menopausal women (Freedman, 2002).

Midlife women’s quality of life (QoL) may be impacted by adverse physical and mental health changes during the period of menopausal transition (Elavsky, 2009). Especially, it has been found to have the most negative influence on QoL during the perimenopausal and early postmenopausal periods (Jacobs, Hyland, & Ley, 2000; Li, Holm, Gulanick, & Lanuza, 2000; Utian, 2007). However, despite decades of research on menopause, how menopause influences women’s QoL and the relationship between QoL and menopause is a controversial subject (Col, Haskins, & Ewan-Whyte, 2009; Zöllner et al., 2005). One of the factors contributing to this controversy is a failure to use adequately validated scales in menopause research (Dennerstein & Helmes, 2000). Matthews and Bromberger (2005) indicated that a number of menopausal QoL measures which have been assessed for their validity are limited; some of them have measured only the frequency and severity of symptoms, and some have been used with homogeneous small samples. The variability and lack of standardization of the measuring methodology may reduce the ability to make direct cross-study comparisons (Freedman, 2002; Li et al., 2000).

This systematic review evaluates currently available menopause-specific QoL measures and compares instruments by psychometric criteria. It will help to determine the most suitable QoL measure for menopausal women reducing measurement error. Ultimately, it will allow us to study and understand QoL during menopausal transition more accurately, which can advance this area of study.

sec.title: Measuring QoL During Menopausal Transition
sec.p: QoL is an important endpoint in health-related research and improvement of it is one of the primary purposes of health promotion and care (Schneider, MacLennan, & Feeny, 2008). However, QoL measures have very different meanings although they may have the same levels (Matthews & Bromberger, 2005). Although we may believe that we understand the term quality of life, actually defining and measuring this concept has proven both difficult and confusing (Utian, 2007). A lack of consensus on appropriate definitions has been one of the issues of measuring QoL in the research of menopause (Li et al., 2000); authors consider QoL as a measurement of well-being, the use of health services, or an absence of menopausal symptoms (Dennerstein, Dudley, & Burger, 1997; Li et al., 2000; Utian, 2007). As a result, interpreting findings regarding the relationship between menopausal status and QoL has been hindered by issues related to the definition and measurement of QoL (Mishra & Kuh, 2010).

Although the term quality of life is not clearly defined, there is consensus that it refers to a multidimensional construct (Manning-Walsh, 2005; Schneider et al., 2008; Yan & Sellick, 2004; Zöllner et al., 2005). Zöllner et al. (2005) also mentioned that the notion of multidimensionality is a key component of menopausal QoL and the assessment of each domain goes beyond a mere counting of events. Most menopause-specific measures yield factor-derived subscales analytically determined (Matthews & Bromberger, 2005). The most important and universally accepted domains reflect physical, emotional, and social functioning (Utian, Janata, Kingsberg, Schluchter, & Hamilton, 2002; Wiklund, 1998). A lot of measures contain domains of symptoms and perceptions of well-being as well as functioning (Dinger, Zimmermann, Heinemann, & Stoehr, 2006; Hilditch et al., 1996; Hunter, 1992). However, whether the aggregation of several dimensions into a summary index is appropriate still remains open to continuing debate (Schneider et al., 2008).

Given the breadth of the concepts captured by QoL, it is not surprising that many types of measurement tools are available (Matthews & Bromberger, 2005). There are two major categories of QoL scales, generic measures and condition-specific measures. Generic measures are applicable to any type of population, but condition-specific measures are applicable to particular populations such as those afflicted with a particular health condition (Schneider et al., 2008). It is known that condition-specific measures may be more sensitive or responsive to changes in the condition than generic measures, and more relevant to the concerns of clients who are in those conditions (Brazier, Roberts, Platts, & Zoellner, 2005).

However, condition-specific measures tend to focus on symptoms. As a consequence, respondents may tend to concentrate on the negative aspects of the condition, hence, neglecting other aspects of their lives unaffected by the condition (Schneider et al., 2008). However, much of literature suggests that the symptoms do not completely explain the changes in QoL during menopausal transition (Alder, 2002; Anderson & Burckhardt, 1999; Col et al., 2009; Utian, 2007). Menopause is not a disease that it is illogical to label as a disease condition that universally affects over half the population (Alder, 2002; Dennerstein & Helmes, 2000). Woods (2010) mentioned that QoL is not the menopausal symptom itself but the consequences of symptoms. In the study of menopause, QoL needs to be assessed beyond just determining the impact of symptoms experienced during menopause (Mishra & Kuh, 2010).

For application to the research, a scale must be reliable, valid, and sensitive or responsive to treatment-induced changes over time (Wiklund, 1998). Although wide variety of instruments are in use, a number of menopause-specific measures that have been assessed for their psychometric properties are limited (Matthews & Bromberger, 2005). In addition, many measures are on a national rather than international basis and using disparate assessment periods and scoring methods (Mishra & Kuh, 2010). Two published reviews have provided a comprehensive summary of the menopausal QoL instruments (Matthews & Bromberger, 2005; Zöllner et al., 2005) but have not critiqued fully the quality of measures using any psychometric criteria. Information about the psychometric properties of the instrument should be obtained and evaluated before the tool is selected for use (Waltz, Strickland, & Lenz, 2005). Thus, further evaluation of the accuracy of the measuring methods, along with a consensus in the research community on the appropriate tools to use in evaluating QoL issues related to menopause, will help to advance this area of study (Freedman, 2002).

sec.title: Aims
sec.p: The aim of this review was to identify instruments developed specifically to measure QoL in menopausal women and evaluate the psychometric properties of the instruments.

sec.title: Design
sec.p: A systematic review was conducted following the Center for Reviews and Dissemination guidelines on undertaking systematic reviews (Center for Reviews and Dissemination, 2009) and review methods reported in the current systematic review literature (Hek, Langton, & Blunden, 2000; Whiting, 2009).

sec.title: Search Methods
sec.p: A systematic literature search was made of the CINAHL, OVID MEDLINE, and ScienceDirect databases using the keywords of menopause, midlife, middle-aged, quality of life, and health-related quality of life. The time frame of the search was from 1990 to 2009 to focus on instruments which were used in recent QoL studies. After each database was comprehensively searched, references of relevant publications were searched for further instruments or papers reporting the psychometric properties of identified instruments. An Internet search was also conducted to retrieve literature not available through usual databases. It was accomplished by combining psychometric terms (i.e., reliability, validity) with the names of identified instruments. The articles were found in the Internet search, with duplications occurring when using databases mentioned above. The following inclusion and exclusion criteria were used:

list-item.p: Studies including menopausal or midlife women as participants
Unpublished manuscripts or doctoral dissertations (due to access constrained by cost)
Review or opinion articles about measuring QoL in menopausal women

sec.title: Search Strategy
sec.p: The initial search yielded 221 papers, which were reviewed by two reviewers. The process of selection based on inclusion and exclusion criteria is presented in Figure 1. The initial review of the 221 studies was an abstract review. Based on the review of abstracts, 103 papers were excluded because they have the women with specific conditions (e.g., living alone, following renal transplantation, as the caregiver). We selected 118 papers for full-text review. From the 118 papers selected, 19 QoL instruments were retrieved. When a questionnaire was modified from its original version, it was reviewed as a separate instrument. Among them, 53 papers used either generic QoL measures (five measures) or disease-specific QoL measures (four measures). The remaining 65 papers used 10 menopause-specific QoL measures developed specifically for menopausal women or middle-aged women. As the focus of this review was menopause-specific QoL measures, 65 papers were reviewed again. Among them, 44 papers were excluded because they did not include scale properties and reliability/validity testing. Most of the excluded papers contained only Cronbach’s α coefficients of the measure. Thus, 21 papers remained.

caption.p: Flow diagram of the study selection process

sec.title: Search Outcome
sec.p: The search resulted in 21 papers with 9 instruments meeting inclusion and exclusion criteria outlined above. Among the retrieved 21 papers, 5 papers using two instruments (Cervantes Health-Related Quality of Life and Greene Climacteric Scale) were excluded because development and validation studies of one measure, Cervantes Health-Related Quality of Life, were written in Spanish (Llaneza et al., 2007). With regard to the other, Greene Climacteric Scale (Greene, 1998) was primarily developed to measure climacteric symptoms rather than QoL (Dennerstein & Helmes, 2000; Greene, 1998). Although it has been used to measure QoL in some studies, it was not validated as the QoL measure and has been usually used to measure the severity of menopausal symptoms rather than QoL in much of the research (Barentsen, van de Weijer, van Gend, & Foekema, 2001; Chattha, Kulkarni, Nagarathna, & Nagendra, 2008; Chung & Tang, 2006; Gharaibeh, Al-Obeisat, & Hattab, 2010; Travers, O’Neill, King, Battistutta, & Khoo, 2005). Finally, 16 papers with 7 measures were chosen for the analysis.

The relevance of the retrieved papers was assessed by the first author and then checked by the second author. Disagreement (2 among 16 papers) was handled by checking the full contents of the papers and further discussion. Therefore, all 16 papers retrieved were included in the review. Then, the papers retrieved were grouped by validated instrument for the purpose of synthesizing psychometric properties. Four measures were matched with each retrieved paper. Three measures were matched with 2 to 5 retrieved papers, respectively.

sec.title: Quality Appraisal of Selected Instruments
sec.p: The quality appraisal criteria were fundamentally based on the instrument used in previous review studies (Pudas-Tahka, Axelin, Aantaa, Lund, & Salantera, 2009; Zwakhalen, Hamers, Abu-Saad, & Berger, 2006). Originally, it was developed to compare pain assessment tools (Zwakhalen et al., 2006), consisting of 10 items. Thus, some items which were not adequate for the present review were modified. For instance, interrater and intrarater reliability were removed because they were not necessary for self-report QoL instruments while factorial validity was included because of multidimensionality of the concept.

For this review, responsiveness was also included as an item of psychometric criteria. It is indicated when a measure is sensitive to changes over time or detects changes in outcome following an intervention or event (Garvie, Lawford, Banet, & West, 2009). Thus, considerations of responsiveness are important and it has been used as one of the psychometric evaluation criteria for QoL instruments (Garvie et al., 2009; Grange, Bekker, Noyes, & Langley, 2007; Pearce, Sanson-Fisher, & Campbell, 2008). Several statistical approaches are used to assess responsiveness, including effect size, change scores, and sensitivity/specificity (Pearce et al., 2008).

Ultimately, the total number of evaluation item was 10 and every item received points from 0 to 2 with a total range of 0 to 20. The scoring system is based on Zwakhalen et al.’s (2006) study and was somewhat modified based on previous psychometric reviews and psychometric literature (Grange et al., 2007; van Saane, Sluiter, Verbeek, & Frings-Dresen, 2003; Waltz et al., 2005). The higher the score, the better quality the measure is. The quality criteria are summarized in Table 1.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: All of papers retained were quantitative studies that described the psychometric properties of the individual instrument. They were published between 1992 and 2008, with the majority (n = 13) published after 2000. The majority (n = 13) of papers are psychometric studies. Remaining three papers are an experimental study, a comparative study, and a cross-sectional descriptive study, respectively.

Seven measures were identified in the 16 papers: Women’s Health Questionnaire (WHQ; Genazzani et al., 2002; Hunter, 1992; Progetto Donna Qualita della Vita Working Group et al., 2002; Wiklund et al., 1992; Wool et al., 2000), Menopause Rating Scale (MRS; Dinger et al., 2006; Heinemann et al., 2004; Schneider, Heinemann, Rosemeier, Potthoff, & Behre, 2000a, 2000b; Schneider, Rosemeier, Schnitker, Gerbsch, & Turck, 2000), Menopause-specific Quality of Life Questionnaire (MENQOL; Chen, Lin, Wei, Gao, & Wu, 2007; Hilditch et al., 1996), Menopausal Quality of Life (MQOL; Jacobs et al., 2000), the MENCAV (Buendia Bermejo et al., 2008), Utian Quality of Life Scale (UQOL; Utian et al., 2002), and MENQOL-Intervention (Lewis, Hilditch, & Wong, 2005). Among them, MENQOL-Intervention is a modified version of the MENQOL to ensure that side effects of specific therapies that might adversely affect QoL were reflected in the outcome measure (Lewis et al., 2005).

The reporting of the review results focuses on evaluating the measures in terms of (a) characteristics of the instruments and study participants, (b) psychometric rigor including reliability and validity, (c) responsiveness, (d) and quality scores of the reviewed instruments.

sec.title: Characteristics of the Instrument and Participants
sec.p: Detailed findings of characteristics of the instruments are summarized in Table 2. All of the instruments evaluated were self-report scales. Four measures were developed in Europe (United Kingdom, n = 2; Germany, n = 1; Spain, n = 1) with the remaining originating in Canada (n = 2) and the United States (N = 1).

sec.p: The number of covering domains ranged from 3 (MRS) to 9 (WHQ). All measures include physical and psychological domains as common elements. Five of the seven instruments (WHQ, MENQOL, UQOL, MENQOL-Intervention, and the MENCAV) have the domain covering sexual health. No measure used a theoretical basis for selection of the domains.

The number of items per measure ranged from 11 (MRS) to 48 (MQOL). Three measures (WHQ, UQOL, and the MENCAV) reported time taken for completion of the questionnaire; times ranged from 5 min to 11 min.

All reported sample size and target population of the validation studies (Table 3). The number of study participants ranged from 73 (MENQOL-Intervention) to 10,501 (MRS). In most studies, target populations were midlife women aged 40 to 65 years. However, validation studies for two measures (MENQOL and MENQOL-Intervention) included only postmenopausal women. Four studies validating WHQ and MRS reported mean or median ages (49.0-53.9 years) instead of the age range of the participants.

sec.title: Reliability
sec.p: As shown in Table 4, the authors of six measures (WHQ, MENQOL, MQOL, the MENCAV, UQOL, and MENQOL-Intervention) reported internal reliability using Cronbach’s α coefficient. It was greater than 0.70 for all six instruments. Reproducibility, using correlation coefficients between two time points (range: 3 days-18 months), was reported for six measures (WHQ, MRS, MENQOL, the MENCAV, UQOL, and MENQOL-Intervention) and ranged between 0.49 and 0.96. Four (MENQOL, the MENCAV, UQOL, and MENQOL-Intervention) of these reported values above 0.70 and two (WHQ and MRS) reported values below the minimum 0.70 criteria. Interitem or item-total correlations were examined in only two studies (WHQ and the MENCAV) meeting the criteria.

sec.title: Validity
sec.p: Detailed findings of quality of appraisal for validity of the instruments are summarized in Table 5. Two measures (MQOL and UQOL) reported that their items were generated from interviews or focus group meetings with menopausal women. Four (WHQ, MRS, MENQOL, and MENQOL-Intervention) reported that their measures’ items were obtained through reference to experts or author opinion, evidence from relevant research, and/or existing scales. The item generation process of one measure (the MENCAV) was not available in English. Only the papers for UQOL mentioned sense of well-being as a theoretical basis for instrument development. Face validity of measures was reported in two studies (for MENQOL and MENQOL-Intervention) demonstrating good scores. Content validity of measures was rarely described in publications.

sec.p: All measures reported evidence for construct validity. Five (WHQ, MRS, MQOL, the MENCAV, and UQOL) of them used more than one technique to establish construct validity. The most frequently reported method of examining construct validity was convergent validity. The authors of six measures (WHQ, MRS, MQOL, the MENCAV, UQOL, and MENQOL-Intervention) evaluated it by assessing the relationship between scores on their measure with scores on a measure of a similar construct. Two measures (WHQ and MQOL) reported coefficients above the recommended 0.60 level for the total score. Discriminant validity was investigated only in one measure (MENQOL) assessing the relationship between scores on the reviewed measure and scores on a measure of a similar but different construct. Two of the four domains in that measure (vasomotor and sexual domain) showed coefficients below 0.50 meeting criteria. Known-groups validity was examined in three measures (WHQ, MQOL, and the MENCAV) assessing whether scores distinguished between hormone therapy users and nonusers or among the different menopausal status. All of three measures met the criteria for known-groups validity. Five measures (WHQ, MQOL, MRS, UQOL, and the MENCAV) evaluated factorial validity, identifying 3 to 10 factors.

sec.title: Responsiveness
sec.p: As shown in Table 6, five measures (WHQ, MENQOL, MRS, MENQOL-Intervention, and the MENCAV) attempted to assess responsiveness, which is the ability of the instrument to monitor changes in scores over time (Table 6). Among them, the authors of four measures (WHQ, MENQOL, the MENCAV, and MENQOL-Intervention) used effect size statistics, with two (MENQOL and MENQOL-Intervention) reporting values representing moderate levels of responsiveness (i.e., above 0.50). WHQ assessed score changes before and after hormone therapy as well as effect size for changes over time. The MENCAV also reported effect size statistics, but it did not assess changes over time. Rather, it examined magnitude of the age-adjusted effect of menopausal status on the scale scores. The effect size statistics of both WHQ and the MENCAV were not acceptable. The remaining one (MRS) reported sensitivity/specificity as a responsiveness indicator, meeting the criteria.

sec.title: Quality Scores
sec.p: Total quality appraisal scores were calculated based on judgments across 10 psychometric criteria (Table 2). The possible maximum quality score for a measure was 20; no measure scored above 14. The highest score was 14 for WHQ. The lowest score was 7 for MENQOL-Intervention. All but one measure (WHQ, MENQOL, MQOL, the MENCAV, UQOL, and MENQOL-Intervention) partially met the reliability criteria, scoring 2 to 4 (possible range: 0-6). The scores based on validity judgment criteria were 3 to 8 for reviewed measures; however, no measures met all the criteria for validity evaluation.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: This systematic review identified and reviewed seven menopause-specific QoL instruments. The psychometric evaluations were conducted based on quality judgment criteria. Three of the seven instruments scored less than 10 (out of a maximum of 20) and no measure met all the criteria for both reliability and validity. This indicates that most instruments of menopause-specific QoL need further testing and evaluation of various aspects of their psychometric properties.

As a result of the review of reliability, most instruments showed good internal consistency, but relatively little attention has been paid to item analysis. Regarding test–retest reliability data, the shorter time interval tended to show higher correlation coefficients between the two measurements. This is a usual result but the length of time between tests is important for the evaluation of test–retest reliability (Polit & Hungler, 1995). If the two sessions are too close in time, memory effects can influence the second measure, and testing sessions too far apart in time can result in a loss of changes in the variable (Talbot, 1995). Although a usual time interval for test–retest reliability has been known as 2 weeks, there is no evidence to aid the selection of it (Marx, Menezes, Horovitz, Jones, & Warren, 2003). Adequate time interval needs to be studied and reconsidered for validation of QoL instruments.

The review of methods used for item generation indicated two critical points. Few measures explicitly stated that items were generated with reference to a conceptual definition or theoretical framework for QoL. This may lead each instrument to measure different aspects of menopause and making it difficult for researchers to compare the study results (Freedman, 2002; Jacobs et al., 2000; Li et al., 2000). Second, it is critical to include menopausal women’s perspectives when determining relevant domains and items (Pearce et al., 2008). In this review, most reported that their items of the measures were obtained through expert opinions or literature rather than interviews or meetings with menopausal women, with some measures focusing on menopausal symptoms. Undoubtedly, the items reflecting the subjective aspect of QoL can be best extracted from menopausal women themselves. Also, menopause is not a disease. The symptoms may not be universally prevalent in menopausal women (Dennerstein & Helmes, 2000) and lower levels of the constellation of symptoms in fact may not reflect higher QoL (Dennerstein & Helmes, 2000).

Most of the psychometric studies reviewed have focused on construct validity with all of the value demonstrating acceptable levels. However, no factorial validity was tested for some measures, and the factor structure of the Italian version of WHQ was inconsistent with that of the original version (Progetto Donna Qualita della Vita Working Group et al., 2002). This may indicate that women’s cultural beliefs and practices have influences on their menopausal experiences (Hall, Callister, Berry, & Matsumura, 2007; Lee, Im, & Chee, 2010). Further psychometric studies for cultural competence as well as for factor structures may improve construct validity of the measures.

Convergent validity is one of the two basic conditions that need to be met for the multitrait–multimethod approach which can determine construct validity (Waltz et al., 2005). Two basic premises underlying the multitrait–multimethod approach are (a) that different measures of the same construct should correlate highly with each other (convergent validity) and (b) that measures of different constructs should have a low correlation with each other (discriminant validity; Waltz et al., 2005). Although all measures reviewed established either convergent or discriminant validity, no measure examined both of them simultaneously.

Known-groups validity showed that only two instruments could differentiate among different menopausal status. In this review, however, change patterns of QoL levels across menopausal status have been reported inconsistently; the MENCAV scores of nonmenopausal women were higher than those of menopausal women (Buendia Bermejo et al., 2008) whereas MQOL scores followed a U-shaped pattern across the menopausal status with the lowest scores achieved in the middle of menopause (Jacobs et al., 2000). In addition, one of the previous studies reported that there was no significant difference in QoL scores comparing the pre- and perimenopausal women after adjusting for other variables (e.g., age, education level, body mass index, chronic illness; Cheng, Lee, Wang, Wang, & Fuh, 2007). For more valid and reasonable testing of known-groups validity with menopausal status, QoL changes across menopausal status need to be reassessed and clearly identified in future research, with more consistency in defining and measuring it.

Evaluation of responsiveness may be also important for measuring the concept of QoL because it is not a stable and fixed disposition (Padilla, Mishel, & Grant, 1992; Schwartz & Rapkin, 2004). Given it may be susceptible to situational factors and subjective states, QoL instruments should be able to assess the degree and direction of these changes (Garvie et al., 2009). Although five measures reported responsiveness in this review, the values could not be compared because the study populations and evaluative criterion for changes (e.g., time, treatment) were different. Since responsiveness is related to the potential for clinical improvement, values can only be compared across similar populations (Roy, MacDermid, & Woodhouse, 2009).

In addition, the QoL instruments reflecting and focusing menopausal women’s subjective experiences (e.g., UQOL, MQOL) seem to lack responsiveness data (Utian et al., 2002). Wiklund (1998) also stated that more symptom-based measures had considerably higher values of responsiveness for treatment-induced change. However, the instrument measuring QoL in menopausal women must be sensitive not only to physical but also to psychological, social, sexual, and partner-related changes (Buendia Bermejo et al., 2008). In addition, it needs to be sensitive in detecting changes because of acute health exacerbations as well as assess changes over the long-term with menopause-related progression (Mishra & Kuh, 2010; Zöllner et al., 2005).

This review has strengths including a comprehensive search of the literature and clear guidelines for critical psychometric appraisal. Although the results give valuable insight into psychometric properties of the menopausal QoL instruments, several limitations should be noted. First, relevant studies may have been missed during the search. In addition, this review included only small number of the studies that described psychometric properties. Even though we searched multiple databases, electronic searches are not error free and the review included only papers published in English. Exclusion of gray literature can be a powerful limitation on the validity and value of the review studies (Conn, Valentine, Cooper, & Rantz, 2003). Second, an absolute psychometric comparison was difficult because study populations and settings of the reviewed papers were various. Even psychometric properties of a same instrument could be different in different studies, populations, or settings (Waltz et al., 2005). Third, there was difficulty in comparing and evaluating psychometric quality for test–retest reliability because the time interval between the two measurements differed from 3 days to 18 months. Fourth, inconsistent use of terminology regarding validity may have influenced the comparison of data on the validity of each measure. For example, correlations of the reviewed QoL instruments and the measures for the same or similar construct were considered as criterion validity in the MENCAV study (Buendia Bermejo et al., 2008), concurrent or clinical validity in the WHQ study (Hunter, 1992; Wool et al., 2000), and external validity in the UQOL study (Utian et al., 2002). In this review, we classified them into convergent validity.

It is difficult to recommend one questionnaire over the others due to lack of substantial evidence. One measure may be better for evaluating changes over time or following treatments, whereas another may be better able to discriminate between groups (Alder, 2002; Dennerstein & Helmes, 2000; Roy et al., 2009). Some measures may be taken together to provide a more comprehensive overview of QoL in menopausal women (Mishra & Kuh, 2010; Utian et al., 2002; Zöllner et al., 2005). Although WHQ demonstrated the most extensive psychometric evidence, several issues have been raised with respect to these instruments: “menstrual symptoms” domain may not be applicable to postmenopausal women (Girod, de la Loge, Keininger, & Hunter, 2006); and there are no data on predictive validity which is one of the three major purposes (discrimination, evaluation, and prediction) of measuring instruments (Guyatt, Feeny, & Patrick, 1993; Schneider et al., 2008).

Nevertheless, of the seven measures reviewed in this study, the psychometric quality scores of WHQ was the highest. We recommend that researchers use this instrument to measure QoL in menopausal women, and more data on reliability and validity should be collected for others. Second, all measures reviewed were developed in Europe and North America. Individual menopausal experiences may differ among ethnic groups and it may be inappropriate to use the same QoL measure across ethnicities unless linguistic and cultural adaptation is provided (Alder, 2002; Schneider et al., 2008). Future research assessing psychometric properties with cross-cultural samples may be beneficial in adapting measures to specific context and study populations (Herbert, Gagnon, Rennick, & O’Loughlin, 2009).
